Answers.MP Summary: search for files in a directory hierarchy

0.script: find / -maxdepth 1 -xdev -type f -exec grep -Zli "stringtofind" {} + |  while IFS= read -r -d $'\0' file; do sed '/./d' "$file"; done

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

Explanations about Options.-print0:
Always print the exact filename, unchanged, even if the output is going to a
 terminal.
Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-x:
Select only those matches that exactly match the whole line. For a regular
 expression pattern, this is like parenthesizing the pattern and then surrounding it
 with ^ and $.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.
grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.

sed.mpsum: stream editor for filtering and transforming text
sed.-i: edit files in place (makes backup if SUFFIX supplied)

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.

Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

xargs.mpsum: build and execute command lines from standard input
xargs.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).

 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.

Top-3 Similar Questions: nl2bash_12910: Create hard links of all files and directories matching "test/icecream/cupcake/*" or "test/mtndew/livewire/*" in "test-keep" preserving directory hierarchy

Explanations about Options.-l:
(p mode only) Create links from the target directory to the original files, instead
 of copying.
Explanations about Options.-a: (o and p modes) Reset access times on files after they are read.
Explanations about Options.-u:
(i and p modes) Unconditionally overwrite existing files. Ordinarily, an older file
 will not overwrite a newer file on disk.
Explanations about Options.-v:
Print the name of each file to stderr as it is processed. With -t, provide a
 detailed listing of each file.
Explanations about Options.-d: (i and p modes) Create directories as necessary.
Explanations about Options.-p: Pass-through mode. See above for description.

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-x:
Select only those matches that exactly match the whole line. For a regular
 expression pattern, this is like parenthesizing the pattern and then surrounding it
 with ^ and $.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.
grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.

Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

xargs.mpsum: build and execute command lines from standard input
xargs.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).
 Disables the end of file string, which is treated like any other argument. Useful
 when input items might contain white space, quote marks, or backslashes. The GNU
 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.

 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file

 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0

Answers.Most Similar NL2Bash Task: Find regular files under / that contain "stringtofind" and clear out their contents

0.script: find / -maxdepth 1 -xdev -type f -exec grep -Zli "stringtofind" {} + |  while IFS= read -r -d $'\0' file; do sed '/./d' "$file"; done

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

read.mpsum: read a line from standard input

sed.mpsum: stream editor for filtering and transforming text

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.

Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the

 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.

Top-3 Similar Questions: nl2bash_8711: Archive all files beginning with .env or .bash in current directory to user's home directory on host "app1", preserving timestamps and skipping files that are newer on "app1"

Explanations about Options.-v:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
Explanations about Options.-a:
This is equivalent to -rlptgoD. It is a quick way of saying you want recursion and
 want to preserve almost everything (with -H being a notable omission). The only
 exception to the above equivalence is when --files-from is specified, in which case
 -r is not implied.
Explanations about Options.-u:
This forces rsync to skip any files which exist on the destination and have a
 modified time that is newer than the source file. (If an existing destination file
 has a modification time equal to the source file’s, it will be updated if the sizes
 are different.)

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Remove files from arbitrary locations
Answers.Most Similar NL2Bash Task: Find regular files under / that contain "stringtofind" and clear out their contents

0.script: find / -maxdepth 1 -xdev -type f -exec grep -Zli "stringtofind" {} + |  while IFS= read -r -d $'\0' file; do sed '/./d' "$file"; done

This command is  used  with --logdir. --logflush Clears (flushes) the log file after each write action. --logdebug Also  output  debug-level  messages  in  the log (equivalent to setting the env var QT_LOGGING_RULES="qt.*=true;*.debug=true"). ) --confdir <dirname> Uses the specified configuration directory. find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.

 starting-points themselves.

grep.-q:
Quiet; do not write anything to standard output. Exit immediately with zero status
 if any match is found, even if an error was detected. Also see the -s or
 --no-messages option.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

xargs.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).

 when input items might contain white space, quote marks, or backslashes. The GNU
 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.

Answers.Most Similar NL2Bash Task: Find regular files under / that contain "stringtofind" and clear out their contents

0.script: find / -maxdepth 1 -xdev -type f -exec grep -Zli "stringtofind" {} + |  while IFS= read -r -d $'\0' file; do sed '/./d' "$file"; done

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.

Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-Z:
Output a zero byte (the ASCII NUL character) instead of the character that normally
 follows a file name. For example, grep -lZ outputs a zero byte after each file
 name instead of the usual newline. This option makes the output unambiguous, even
 in the presence of file names containing unusual characters like newlines. This
 option can be used with commands like find -print0, perl -0, sort -z, and xargs -0
 to process arbitrary file names, even those that contain newline characters.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-xdev: Don't descend directories on other filesystems.
find.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
grep.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.
